articles.headline: Are Tesla and Texas a Perfect Match? It’s Questionable.
articles.snippet: While its C.E.O., Elon Musk, and the state’s conservative lawmakers share libertarian sensibilities, they differ greatly on climate change and renewable energy.
articles.abstract: While its C.E.O., Elon Musk, and the state’s conservative lawmakers share libertarian sensibilities, they differ greatly on climate change and renewable energy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tesla’s move from Silicon Valley to Texas makes sense in many ways: The company’s chief executive, Elon Musk, and the conservative lawmakers who run the state share a libertarian philosophy, favoring few regulations and low taxes. Texas also has room for a company with grand ambitions to grow.
articles.byline: By Niraj Chokshi, Clifford Krauss and Ivan Penn

articles.headline: 2 Parents Are Convicted in the Varsity Blues Admissions Trial
articles.snippet: John Wilson, a private equity financier, and Gamal Abdelaziz, a former casino executive, were the first people to stand trial in the federal investigation.
articles.abstract: John Wilson, a private equity financier, and Gamal Abdelaziz, a former casino executive, were the first people to stand trial in the federal investigation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two parents were found guilty in federal court in Boston on Friday for participating in a bribery scheme to have their children fraudulently admitted as athletic recruits to some of the most prestigious universities in the country.

articles.headline: Benefits for All or Just the Needy? Manchin’s Demand Focuses Debate
articles.snippet: As Democrats ponder cutting a $3.5 trillion social safety net bill down to perhaps $2 trillion, a proposal to limit programs to the poor has rekindled a debate on the meaning of government itself.
articles.abstract: As Democrats ponder cutting a $3.5 trillion social safety net bill down to perhaps $2 trillion, a proposal to limit programs to the poor has rekindled a debate on the meaning of government itself.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Joe Manchin III of West Virginia has a ready retort to fellow Democrats who say shrinking the party’s social safety net bill will mean depriving vulnerable populations of critical resources: Limit access to every program in the ambitious measure to only those Americans who need it most.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Weisman and Emily Cochrane

articles.headline: Debate Looms Over I.M.F.: Should It Do More Than Put Out Fires?
articles.snippet: As the International Monetary Fund gets set for its annual meeting, economists ask if it’s time to update its mandate as the world’s financial crisis responder.
articles.abstract: As the International Monetary Fund gets set for its annual meeting, economists ask if it’s time to update its mandate as the world’s financial crisis responder.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lopsided access to vaccinations, extreme economic inequality, rising food prices and staggering debt are on the agenda when the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank gather for their annual meetings in Washington next week.

articles.headline: Lawmakers See Path to Rein In Tech, but It Isn’t Smooth
articles.snippet: If what faces Big Tech is anything like what happened to Big Tobacco, the road ahead is likely to be a yearslong battle over proposed rules and regulations.
articles.abstract: If what faces Big Tech is anything like what happened to Big Tobacco, the road ahead is likely to be a yearslong battle over proposed rules and regulations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — “Facebook and Big Tech are facing a Big Tobacco moment,” Senator Richard Blumenthal, Democrat of Connecticut, said this week when a whistle-blower testified about how the social media company’s products harmed teenagers.

articles.headline: Candidate for ‘Mayah’ Proudly Leans Into Her Boston Sound
articles.snippet: The mayoral candidate Annissa Essaibi George, the daughter of Polish and Tunisian immigrants, speaks with the accent of working-class Boston. And she’s having some fun with it.
articles.abstract: The mayoral candidate Annissa Essaibi George, the daughter of Polish and Tunisian immigrants, speaks with the accent of working-class Boston. And she’s having some fun with it.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The mayoral candidate Annissa Essaibi George was amping up her supporters, who had gathered in an Italian restaurant on the waterfront, a little punchy after a long day of getting out the vote.

articles.headline: ‘Starting a Fire’: U.S. and China Enter Dangerous Territory Over Taiwan
articles.snippet: The self-ruled island has moved to the heart of deepening discord and rivalry between the two superpowers, with the potential to ignite military conflagration and reshape the regional order.
articles.abstract: The self-ruled island has moved to the heart of deepening discord and rivalry between the two superpowers, with the potential to ignite military conflagration and reshape the regional order.
articles.lead_paragraph: The 25 Chinese fighter jets, bombers and other warplanes flew in menacing formations off the southern end of Taiwan, a show of military might on China’s National Day, Oct. 1. The incursions, dozens upon dozens, continued into the night and the days that followed and surged to the highest numbers ever on Monday, when 56 warplanes tested Taiwan’s beleaguered air defenses.
articles.byline: By Chris Buckley and Steven Lee Myers

articles.headline: Moderna, Racing for Profits, Keeps Covid Vaccine Out of Reach of Poor
articles.snippet: Some poorer countries are paying more and waiting longer for the company’s vaccine than the wealthy — if they have access at all.
articles.abstract: Some poorer countries are paying more and waiting longer for the company’s vaccine than the wealthy — if they have access at all.
articles.lead_paragraph: Moderna, whose coronavirus vaccine appears to be the world’s best defense against Covid-19, has been supplying its shots almost exclusively to wealthy nations, keeping poorer countries waiting and earning billions in profit.

articles.headline: 52 Years in 11 Days: A Son, Facing Death, Finds His Father
articles.snippet: After struggling with cancer for years, Sam Anthony was running out of time. Before he died, he found the courage to mail a letter that he had long been afraid to send.
articles.abstract: After struggling with cancer for years, Sam Anthony was running out of time. Before he died, he found the courage to mail a letter that he had long been afraid to send.
articles.lead_paragraph: FALLS CHURCH, Va. — Three weeks before he died, Sam Anthony, 52, mailed his last wishes to a man he had never met.

articles.headline: When Child Care Costs Twice as Much as the Mortgage
articles.snippet: President Biden’s social policy legislation aims to address a problem that weighs on many families — and the teachers and child care centers serving them.
articles.abstract: President Biden’s social policy legislation aims to address a problem that weighs on many families — and the teachers and child care centers serving them.
articles.lead_paragraph: GREENSBORO, N.C. — To understand the problems Democrats hope to solve with their supersized plan to make child care better and more affordable, consider this small Southern city where many parents spend more for care than they do for mortgages, yet teachers get paid like fast food workers and centers cannot hire enough staff.

articles.headline: A Year After ‘Defund,’ Police Departments Get Their Money Back
articles.snippet: The abrupt reversals have come in response to rising levels of crime, the exodus of officers and political pressures.
articles.abstract: The abrupt reversals have come in response to rising levels of crime, the exodus of officers and political pressures.
articles.lead_paragraph: DALLAS — The demonstrators came at night, chanting and blowing whistles outside the home of Mayor Eric Johnson, protesting in occasionally personal terms his staunch refusal to cut funding to the Dallas Police Department.

articles.headline: Finally Time for ‘No Time to Die’? The Champagne’s Been on Ice.
articles.snippet: For brands associated with the Bond franchise, the connection is valuable enough to throw do-over parties for the latest film.
articles.abstract: For brands associated with the Bond franchise, the connection is valuable enough to throw do-over parties for the latest film.
articles.lead_paragraph: One day before “No Time to Die” started playing in American theaters on Friday, Bollinger, James Bond’s Champagne of choice, held a pre-screening bash at a swanky theater in New York’s South Street Seaport. V.I.P.s in sequined dresses and tuxedos posed for photos on the red carpet, ate caviar and drank a limited edition wine dedicated to 007 — both during the movie and for hours afterward.

articles.headline: ‘It’s Not Sustainable’: What America’s Port Crisis Looks Like Up Close
articles.snippet: An enduring traffic jam at the Port of Savannah reveals why the chaos in global shipping is likely to persist.
articles.abstract: An enduring traffic jam at the Port of Savannah reveals why the chaos in global shipping is likely to persist.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAVANNAH, Ga. — Like toy blocks hurled from the heavens, nearly 80,000 shipping containers are stacked in various configurations at the Port of Savannah — 50 percent more than usual.
articles.byline: By Peter S. Goodman and Erin Schaff

articles.headline: Black Lives Matter, She Wrote. Then ‘Everything Just Imploded.’
articles.snippet: A Black superintendent’s email to parents after the killing of George Floyd engulfed a small, predominantly white Maryland community in a yearlong firestorm.
articles.abstract: A Black superintendent’s email to parents after the killing of George Floyd engulfed a small, predominantly white Maryland community in a yearlong firestorm.
articles.lead_paragraph: CENTREVILLE, Md. — When Andrea Kane sat down to write a letter to parents in her school district days after George Floyd’s death in 2020, images of the Black man pleading for his life under the knee of a white Minnesota police officer were haunting her.

articles.headline: After Whistle-Blower Goes Public, Facebook Tries Calming Employees
articles.snippet: Employees are divided over Frances Haugen, a former product manager who testified that the company was putting profit before safety.
articles.abstract: Employees are divided over Frances Haugen, a former product manager who testified that the company was putting profit before safety.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — At a question-and-answer session with employees last week, Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, was asked about Frances Haugen, a former product manager turned whistle-blower who had testified to Congress about the company’s harms.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac, Ryan Mac and Sheera Frenkel

articles.headline: James Bond Returns and Theaters See Reason for Hope
articles.snippet: “No Time to Die” has taken in more than $300 million worldwide. The overall box office remains fragile, however, and the future for films that aren’t part of big-budget franchises is unsure.
articles.abstract: “No Time to Die” has taken in more than $300 million worldwide. The overall box office remains fragile, however, and the future for films that aren’t part of big-budget franchises is unsure.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Movie theaters are finally bouncing back from the pandemic, with solid turnout over the weekend for the latest James Bond spectacle, “No Time to Die,” giving Hollywood its third box office success in the span of a month. For coronavirus-battered multiplex chains, it’s reason for a celebratory martini.

articles.headline: Two Journalists Started an Argument in Boston in 1979. It’s Not Over Yet.
articles.snippet: A writer for an alt-weekly called out a Boston Globe editor for his “fealty” to the idea of objectivity in a column that reads as if it were written yesterday.
articles.abstract: A writer for an alt-weekly called out a Boston Globe editor for his “fealty” to the idea of objectivity in a column that reads as if it were written yesterday.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 1979, two journalists got into an argument. More than four decades later, they haven’t settled it.

articles.headline: Inside the Courtroom With Theranos’s Elizabeth Holmes
articles.snippet: Behind the closed doors are whispers, gestures and a daily rhythm, plus two court artists, numbered tickets and some true-crime fans.
articles.abstract: Behind the closed doors are whispers, gestures and a daily rhythm, plus two court artists, numbered tickets and some true-crime fans.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Calif. — Three days a week, Adriana Kratzmann, an administrator, opens the door at 8:30 a.m. to Courtroom 4 of the Robert F. Peckham Federal Building and U.S. Courthouse.
articles.byline: By Erin Woo and Erin Griffith

articles.headline: Bashar al-Assad Steps In From the Cold, but Syria Is Still Shattered
articles.snippet: Arab countries are gradually restoring ties with Syria, but its president remains mired in crises he can’t escape.
articles.abstract: Arab countries are gradually restoring ties with Syria, but its president remains mired in crises he can’t escape.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — For a man who has spent the last decade battling armed rebels, being shunned in international forums and watching a brutal civil war dismantle his economy, the past few weeks have been good to President Bashar al-Assad of Syria.

articles.headline: Seeding Accounts for Kindergartners and Hoping to Grow College Graduates
articles.snippet: New York City is giving every public school kindergartner $100 in a college savings account. Here’s why every penny matters.
articles.abstract: New York City is giving every public school kindergartner $100 in a college savings account. Here’s why every penny matters.
articles.lead_paragraph: Kindergarten often brings a flood of notices about events, school supplies and class photos. But when Vaniqua Hudson-Figueroa’s daughter started at a public school in Queens, there was one that Ms. Hudson-Figueroa wasn’t expecting: The city had opened a college savings account in her child’s name — and it already had $100 in it.
